input.plot: Red pushes open the creaking gate, feeling the rough wood beneath her palm. She knocks on the cottage door, listening as the wind whistles through the eaves. The door opens slowly with a groan. Red steps inside, her boots squeaking on the warped floorboards. She notices 'Grandma' lying in bed, hidden under a thick patchwork quilt, only her face visible in the dim glow of the hearth. The figure beckons her closer, voice raspy—'Come in, dear.' Red moves toward the bed, setting her basket on the wooden table, glancing around at the unfamiliar, musky scent in the room and the oddly long-fingered hand resting on the quilt. The Wolf, disguised as Grandma, keeps his head turned away from the light, pulling the covers higher. He fixes his yellow eyes on Red, urging her to approach—'Let me see you better, child.' Red hesitates, scanning the room, but obeys, motivated to care for her grandmother as her mother instructed. The Wolf, intent on his meal, draws her closer, licking his lips as he pats the bed beside him. The tension between them increases: Red inches forward, the Wolf's tail twitching under the quilt, each maneuvering toward their own goal—Red to tend her ailing grandmother, the Wolf to strike when she is close enough.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Why, don't be shy, my dear. It's just me—your grandmother. Come closer, let me see you better. The light in here is so dim.
dialogue.action: The Wolf, cloaked in grandmother's nightgown, pats the quilt beside him invitingly, his eyes glinting in the shadows as he tries to sound gentle, masking the hunger beneath his words.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Oh, Grandmother, you sound a little strange—are you feeling alright?
dialogue.action: Red hesitates at the threshold, clutching her basket tighter, peering into the dimly lit room.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Ah, it's only the chill of age, child—come nearer so I can hold your hand.
dialogue.action: The Wolf stretches a clawed hand toward the edge of the bed, its eyes glinting softly in the gloom.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Well, I suppose a little closer won't hurt, Grandmother, but you do seem different today.
dialogue.action: Red takes a cautious step forward, her basket clutched tightly in her hands, eyes scanning the shadowed room.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Different, my dear? It must be these old eyes—come, step into the light so I can see your sweet face.
dialogue.action: The Wolf pats the quilted bedspread invitingly, its sharp gaze fixed hungrily on Red.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: If you're sure, Grandmother, I'll come closer—but your eyes look so big and bright in the shadows.
dialogue.action: Red takes a hesitant step forward, clutching her basket to her chest and peering into the gloom.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: The better to see your lovely smile, child—don't be afraid, come just a bit nearer.
dialogue.action: The Wolf lifts a trembling, clawed hand, beckoning Red forward with a crooked finger, its gaze fixed hungrily on her.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Alright, Grandmother, but your voice is so deep and gravelly—are you sure you’re feeling yourself?
dialogue.action: Red hesitates at the foot of the bed, clutching her basket tightly, her eyes searching the shadowed face beneath the bonnet.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Of course, dear—sometimes a cold makes one's voice rough, but your warmth will surely soothe me; come, sit by my side.
dialogue.action: The Wolf pats the edge of the bed invitingly, its eyes glittering with anticipation.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: If it will help you feel better, Grandmother, I’ll sit right here beside you—but your hands look so large and strong today.
dialogue.action: Red hesitantly perches on the edge of the bed, her gaze lingering on the Wolf’s hands as she clutches her basket tightly.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: The better to hold you close, my darling—won’t you give your poor grandmother a hug?
dialogue.action: The Wolf stretches out its great, furry arms invitingly, claws just hidden beneath the blanket.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Well, if it will comfort you, Grandmother, I suppose I can give you a little hug.
dialogue.action: Red hesitantly steps forward, her arms half-raised, eyes flickering with uncertainty as she glances at the Wolf's oversized hands.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Such a sweet child—lean in, now, let me embrace you properly.
dialogue.action: The Wolf opens its arms wide, teeth glinting faintly beneath the shadowed bonnet as it waits for Red to step closer.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Alright, Grandmother, here I am—please don’t squeeze too tightly.
dialogue.action: Red hesitantly leans forward, arms outstretched, watching the shadowy figure with wary eyes.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Come closer, my dear. There's no need to be shy—it's just your old grandmother. Let me see your sweet face in the light.
dialogue.action: The Wolf, draped in grandmother's nightgown and cap, nestles into the bed, his yellow eyes gleaming as he gestures invitingly to Red. His voice is gentle, but beneath the words, a subtle hunger flickers in his gaze.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, your eyes seem so much brighter and bigger than I remember—are you feeling quite well?
dialogue.action: Red hesitates at the foot of the bed, clutching her basket tighter as she peers into the shadowed face beneath the covers.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Ah, my dear, the better to see you with—these old eyes must work harder in the dim light of the forest cottage.
dialogue.action: The Wolf leans forward, his gaze fixed intently on Red, a smile curling at the edge of his sharp mouth.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Your hands look so large and strong tonight, Grandmother—did you do something different while I was away?
dialogue.action: Red hesitates, glancing nervously at the Wolf's outstretched paws before inching a step closer.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Why, my child, the better to hold you close with—so you won't slip away from me so easily.
dialogue.action: The Wolf stretches out a clawed hand, beckoning Red nearer, his smile widening just a little too much.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, your voice sounds so deep and strange—are you sure it's only the chill of the woods?
dialogue.action: Red clutches her basket a little tighter, taking a cautious step closer, her eyes searching the shadowed face beneath the bedclothes.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Oh, my precious, the better to speak to you with—sometimes a long wait makes one's voice grow quite hungry for conversation.
dialogue.action: The Wolf parts his lips in a sly smile, his sharp teeth just barely visible as he leans forward, golden eyes unwavering.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, why are your teeth so sharp and long—I don’t remember them being like that before.
dialogue.action: Red hesitates at the foot of the bed, her basket clutched tightly as she squints, her brow furrowing with unease.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: All the better to eat you with, my dear.
dialogue.action: The Wolf bares his gleaming teeth in a wicked grin, tensing as if ready to spring.

input.plot: The Wolf crouched low behind a clump of ferns, ears flicking at the distant caw of a crow. Driven by hunger and the memory of Red's words in the woods, he slunk from shadow to shadow, blending with the mottled patterns of sunlight on the ground. Near the cottage, he sniffed the air, catching the scent of baking bread and illness—Grandma's scent, weak but distinct. He circled the cottage, claws scraping softly against the weathered wood as he found a loose window latch. With practiced stealth, he nudged it open, the hinges creaking just loud enough to draw Grandma's attention. Her voice quavered from inside, demanding to know who was there. The Wolf instantly mimicked Red's tone, softening his growl to a girlish pitch, and called, 'It's me, Grandma—Red, I've brought you bread and honey.' His tail flicked with anticipation as he slipped through the window, nose twitching at the mingled aromas of herbs and wool blankets. Grandma, motivated by longing for her granddaughter and trust in her voice, hobbled toward the parlor, unaware of the Wolf's true nature. The Wolf lunged, his movements quick and silent, and forced Grandma into the wardrobe, slamming the door shut and wedging a chair under the handle. Seizing her nightcap and shawl, he donned them, his claws curling awkwardly beneath the soft fabric, and settled under the heavy quilts. The Wolf's objective—to deceive Red and claim his meal—was now set, his disguise in place as he listened for distant footsteps approaching on the forest path.

dialogue.speaker: Grandma
dialogue.dialogue: Who is it? I wasn't expectin' anyone at this hour... Speak up now, or I'll call for help!
dialogue.action: Grandma clutches her shawl tighter around her shoulders, her voice shaky but determined as she peers nervously toward the door.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: It's me, Grandma—Red, I've brought you bread and honey!
dialogue.action: The Wolf presses his snout closer to the door, smoothing his fur and pitching his voice to a sweet, trembling lilt. He hides his claws behind his basket, glancing nervously to ensure no trace of his true nature slips through.

input.plot: Red, dressed in her scarlet cloak, kneels beside the herb garden, carefully snipping thyme and tucking it into her basket. She glances toward the cottage as her mother steps onto the threshold, wiping her flour-dusted hands on her apron. Red's mother crosses the yard with brisk steps, her gaze scanning the forest's dark edge. She places a wrapped bundle of bread and a small jar of honey into Red's basket, her hands lingering as she checks the knots. 'Stay to the path, Red. Don't talk to strangers, and come straight back after seeing your grandmother,' she instructs, her voice low and firm. Red straightens, meeting her mother's eyes, and nods, gripping the basket's handle tighter. Determined to show her independence, Red reassures her mother, 'I remember, Mama. I'll be careful.' As Red steps toward the forest path, her mother gently catches her shoulder, pausing to tuck a loose strand of hair behind Red's ear before releasing her. The sun glimmers through the leaves, and Red sets off, the weight of her mother's warning and her own resolve guiding her first steps into the shadowy woods.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.dialogue: Red, remember what I told you—stay to the path, no matter what. The woods can be tricky, and it's easy to lose your way if you wander. Promise me you'll listen, dear. It's for your own safety.
dialogue.action: Red's Mother gently places a hand on Red's shoulder, her eyes full of worry as she adjusts Red's hood and glances toward the edge of the woods.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.dialogue: Red, remember what I said: don't talk to strangers, and come straight back home after you've seen your grandmother.
dialogue.action: She kneels down, smoothing Red’s cloak with careful hands, her eyes searching Red’s face for understanding.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Don't worry, Mama—I remember everything you told me. I can take care of myself, I promise!
dialogue.action: Red stands taller, her basket in hand, looking her mother in the eyes with a confident smile.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: I promise, I'll be careful! I know the woods can be tricky, but I won't stray from the path, no matter what.
dialogue.action: Red ties her cloak a little tighter around her shoulders, her eyes shining with determination as she steps toward the forest's edge.

dialogue.speaker: Little Red Riding Hood (Red)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother's waiting for me, and I won't let anything distract me—not even the prettiest flowers or the friendliest animals.
dialogue.action: Red tightens her grip on the basket and sets her jaw in determination, glancing once more at the winding forest path ahead.

input.plot: Red paused on the winding trail, adjusting the basket of bread and herbs she carried for her grandmother. She knelt to inspect a cluster of wild violets, her fingers brushing the soft petals, when a low rustle in the undergrowth snapped her attention forward. The Wolf emerged, his grey coat mottled with shadows, head lowered in a feigned gesture of curiosity. Rather than immediately focusing on his predatory motives, the Wolf engaged Red in philosophical conversation about solitude, weaving in personal musings about loneliness, regret, and self-discovery. His manner was smooth and inviting, and though he hinted at hunger, he lingered more on the subject of being alone in the woods, perhaps aiming to lower Red's guard through empathetic vulnerability. Red straightened, grip tightening on her basket, recalling her mother’s warnings, but was also drawn to the Wolf's words. She replied, 'To my grandmother’s cottage, just past the brook.' The Wolf continued, 'Alone. The word itself bites colder than the wind...' and shared his reflections, subtly seeking information about Red and her grandmother while appearing introspective. Red, intent on displaying her maturity, answered, 'She lives alone, but I visit her often. I want to show how responsible I am.' Satisfied with the knowledge gained and feeling he had sufficiently engaged Red's trust, the Wolf dipped his head in farewell before slinking away between the trees, leaving Red to resume her journey, though the shadows now seemed thicker along the path.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Such pretty violets. Grandma will love them.

dialogue.speaker: Wolf
dialogue.line: A thoughtful gift. The woods are kinder to those who aren’t alone, don’t you think?

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I suppose so. But I’m not afraid of walking by myself—I know these paths well.

dialogue.speaker: Wolf
dialogue.line: Bravery is rare in these dark hollows. Still, even the bold grow weary of silence. Does your grandmother not find the quiet heavy?

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: She lives alone, but I visit her often. I want to show how responsible I am.

dialogue.speaker: Wolf
dialogue.line: Responsibility is a heavy cloak for such young shoulders. I once carried one myself—and lost it to the wind.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Maybe you just needed someone to help you carry it. I don’t mind helping Grandma.

dialogue.speaker: Wolf
dialogue.line: Kindness is a rare scent on the wind. Farewell, little one—mind the shadows along your path.

input.plot: Red stood beside the wooden gate, clutching a woven basket packed with bread and herbs. Her mother knelt to adjust the red cloak around Red's shoulders, her fingers brushing away stray leaves. 'Remember, stay on the path. No talking to strangers,' she said, voice tight. Red nodded but glanced toward the twisting trail between the trees, her gaze lingering on the dappled shadows. As her mother closed the gate and turned back to the cottage, Red hesitated, then stepped off the main road onto a narrow deer track, drawn by the sight of wild violets growing in the underbrush. The crunch of twigs under her boots mingled with the distant howl of wind, and Red listened for any sign of movement, alert to the warnings but determined to gather flowers for Grandma. Unseen, the Wolf shifted behind a thicket, nose twitching as he watched the girl stray from safety, his hunger sharpening at her disregard for the rules.

Red staggered backward, her cloak catching on the splintered edge of the bed frame as the Wolf, disguised in Grandma's nightgown, lunged forward with bared teeth. The Wolf snapped at her, claws scraping the floorboards, intent on cornering her against the cottage wall. At that moment, the door crashed open, the Huntsman bursting in with his axe raised. He surveyed the scene quickly, boots thudding as he crossed the room. With deliberate force, he swung the axe handle at the Wolf's shoulder, driving the beast away from Red. The Wolf snarled, hackles raised, and circled toward the back door, but the Huntsman blocked his path, planting himself firmly between the Wolf and the trembling girl. Red scrambled to her feet, clutching the edge of the table for support, her eyes darting between the Wolf and her unexpected rescuer. The Wolf bared his fangs, lips curled, and growled, 'Foolish human, you cannot guard them forever.' The Huntsman tightened his grip on the axe, stating, 'You'll not harm a soul in this cottage.' Red, regaining her footing, scanned the room for anything she could use to help, her determination to protect her grandmother fueling her actions. The standoff filled the cramped space with the heavy thud of hearts and the scent of fear and sweat. The Wolf, realizing he was outmatched, crouched low and prepared to leap for the open window. The scene ended with the Huntsman stepping forward, forcing the Wolf to make a desperate decision.

Red stood anxiously on the porch, her basket clutched in nervous hands as she looked up at her mother. Instead of forbidding Red from traveling alone, her mother offered gentle reassurance, recalling her own experiences in the woods and encouraging Red to trust herself. Though concerned about the dangers, Red voiced her fears of getting lost and encountering wolves, but her mother soothed her, reminding Red that her bright cloak and courage would keep her safe. With a final embrace, her mother sent Red off down the forest path toward Grandma’s cottage, trusting in Red’s strength and the lessons she’d been taught. Red set off, determined yet wary, her mother watching from the porch until Red disappeared into the trees.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Mama, what if I lose my way in the woods? Or if I meet a wolf?

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: I understand your worries, dear, but I walked those woods many times when I was your age. Trust yourself, and remember the lessons I've taught you.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I’ll try to be brave, but it’s hard when the trees feel so big and dark.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: Your red cloak will shine bright through any shadow. And your courage is stronger than you think.

dialogue.speaker: Grandma
dialogue.line: (calling faintly from inside) Don’t rush, Red. Take your time and mind your steps—there’s no hurry when you’re coming to visit me.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I promise, Grandma! I’ll bring you the basket and a good story.

dialogue.speaker: Villagers
dialogue.line: (passing by, murmuring) Be careful, Red. The woods aren’t safe these days.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: She’ll be safe, especially with all of you looking out for each other.

dialogue.speaker: Huntsman
dialogue.line: (appearing at the edge of the village) I’ll keep watch near the old oak. If you need help, just shout, Red.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Thank you, Huntsman. I feel braver knowing everyone’s looking out for me.

dialogue.speaker: Wolf
dialogue.line: (hidden among the trees, to himself) Such a sweet child, so eager. She’ll be easy to follow.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: (embracing Red) Stay on the path, my love. And remember, you’re never truly alone.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I will, Mama. I won’t let you down.
